Treated in a despicable manner by certain persons in Germany and England; if he comes to Paris, can Franklin rescue him from that ruin which knaves have attempted to bring upon him. Sends a copy of his late English edition of Born's Mineralogical Letters.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Account of a visit he paid to Amsterdam and of his conversation with the Factor and M. Van Berkel; England's desire to force Holland into an alliance she wishes to form with Russia and Prussia; has M. Van Berkel's word that Amsterdam will never consent to it; his own opinion as to the relations of Holland, England and France; believes the time to be ripe for working and intriguing at Amsterdam. Report received that the houses at Flushing were purchased by some merchants of Dunkirk; their reasons for this.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning a request from M. Flobergue de la Rocatelle [in French, 1 p.] to forward two packets to America, one to Congress, the other to Gen. Washington; will forward them unless he forbids.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing Mr. Henry Newman and Mr. Thomas Cushing.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Arrived at St. Malo. Mr. Elliot recommended by Capt. Wickes to go out with him as captain of marines; asks for a commission for him; wrote before for a commission for M. de Manay, at present master of the Dolphin.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Recommends Mr. Beaugear and his son to Franklin's kindness; aid they have rendered him in arming and fitting his vessel. Capt. Nicholson's arrival at Nantes with a fine new ship; recommends Mr. Elliot for his captain of marines. Wishes to know how far he may be justifiable in complying with the orders of administration for his governance.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Have had no reply to memorandum of goods shipped on schooner Neptune and of advice as to the Success's departure. Captains Sinclair and Williamson arrived at Boston with naval stores after short and prosperous passages; but have not heard from Honorable Elbridge Gerry to whom they were consigned. Schooner Lively, Captain Nicholas Dupee, twenty-seven days from Newburyport, has arrived with seal oil and whale fins consinged to them. Forwards the enclosed sent through Captain Dupee in their care. English troops have evacuated Brunswick with preciptitation; General Howe may proceed against some of the New England settlements.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: An experienced officer anxious to join the American army; his knowledge of the frontiers of Virginia and Canada.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His desire for glory and his love of war induces him to leave his regiment and throw in his lot with the insurgents; discovered that he could do nothing without express permission from Franklin, which he now craves.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wishes to know if he could obtain remunerative employment as physician and surgeon in the United States.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Houckgeest, A. E. Braam. Zutphen in Gelderland

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

Bernardin de St. Pierre, author of Paul et Virginie, etc. The brother, called Dutailly de St. Pierre, entered the American army and after some disgraceful adventures was sent a prisoner to France and locked up in the Bastille; his release obtained by Franklin; soon after this lost his reason and ended his days in a mad-house.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires to know his future destination and how he is to act in regard to the proceedings of the Admiralty officers at this Port; if he is not despatched soon, it will be necessary to clean his hull again. Recommends Capt. Green, of Philadelphia, if Franklin has any employment for him; as he will do everything in his power to serve the American cause and is very capable of commanding a vessel.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Cannot obtain employment in France; implores Franklin to procure him a position at Boston in whatever regiment he thinks suitable.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Will strictly comply with the orders from the Minister at Paris; very anxious for his present unhappy detention to cease; it hurts him very much to be treated as he is by the Admiralty officers of this Port; if he lives to get back to America will never be persuaded to return to France. Is treated with great civility by the gentlemen of this place. Very greateful for Franklin's approbation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Warns Dr. Franklin against a certain Mr. Wentworth who has been showing to the Dutch Minister of State and others, a copy of what purported to be Franklin's memorial to Count Maurepas, wherein he attempts to excite the French Court to declare openly and immediately in favor of America. Heard there were letters at Nantes announcing Mr. Ramsey's safe arrival at Baltimore. To make France jealous of the Colonies it is reported that letters taken from American vessels state that North America promised to the West India Islands and those of Martinico that if they would assist them with warlike stores North America would, if successful, in turn help them to throw off the yoke of France. Burgoyne occupied Ticonderoga after the Americans evacuated it.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

(In French).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning the trouble between Capt Wickes and his men. Number of persons he has helped with money or a berth on a ship. His uncle's desire to return to America; begs Franklin to see him and advance him twenty louis on his account. His proposals for Mr. Schweighauser's daughter received rather coldly owing to his lack of means; his passion gradually getting the better of all reason and reflection.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Major Lutterlob's letter from Philadelphia speaks of the state of the army as far superior to his expectations. Evacuation of the Jerseys confirmed, as well as the capture of Gen. Prescott.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Certifying that Louis Martin, lieutenant in a South Carolina regiment, has undergone treatment, for a fistula, in the military hospital of La Rochelle.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wishes to become a useful "Subject" of the United States.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Solicits an order from Franklin for shoes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

scopecontent.p: Sending him the second volume of his "Histoire d'Angleterre."
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Will Franklin continue his subscription to Jacquin's Hortus Vindobonensis; sets out for London on Wednesday; has Franklin any commands for his literary friends there.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Offering his services to the American cause.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Disposition he has made of the prizes; difficulties in the way of making haste.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Goes to a rendezvous with Messrs. Chaumont and Holker; the latter desires the letters Franklin promised him. Dr. Bancroft has returned.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is professor of English at the University of Strasbourg; has translated Franklin's Examination in Parliament 1 and followed the text as closely as possible; offers his services in case Franklin desires to have any of his other works translated.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: 1 See Ford's Bibliography of Benjamin Franklin, p. 133, C., 296.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: States that a brother of his went to America twenty-eight years ago and settled in Delaware, Pennsylvania. Writer and a younger brother followed ten years ago. Younger brother entered American army and rose to a captaincy. Writer returned to his native city two and one half years ago to receive an inheritance. Wishes to return to America and epouse patriots' cause. Asks Dr. Franklin's assistance.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Congratulates him on the surrender of General Burgoyne; account of the surrender and the military movements which led up to it; behavior of the American soldiers; skirmishes around Philadelphia. Effect of Burgoyne's surrender on Great Britain and other European countries, and on America. Urges Franklin to secure loans for America. (Conclusion missing.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Congratulating Franklin on the success of the American arms in the Northern Department; introducing Col. de Masasquelle, a member of the Royal Academy of Sciences, to Franklin's notice; his son a colonel in the American artillery and pensioned for life by this State, in consideration of his having introduced the art of founding and boring cannon solid, etc.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Announcing the capture of Gen. Burgoyne and his entire army. Introducing the bearer of the good news, Mr. Jonathan L. Austin.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His only daughter married to Joseph Hixon, Esq., of Monsterrat in West Indies; he left Boston in the spring for London; begs Franklin to forward him the enclosed letter from his wife; should accident bring Mr. Hixon to France, asks Franklin's notice for him.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His former military services; his desire to enter the American army with the rank captain.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The surrender of Burgoyne and his whole army to Gen. Gates has induced the council of Massachusetts to forward an express to the Commissioners at Paris; his son the bearer of this intelligence; begs Franklin to grant him his friendship and countenance.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Guienne Dumouchel, Jean-Baptiste-Eléonor de (commission seeker). Dieppe

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires to obtain a company of infantry or dragoons in the service of Congress.
( In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Mrs. Collas is exceedingly well and quite contented to be delivered from Howe's ravages. Supposes he has heard that Mrs. Bache has a fine daughter; leaves the great news to more intelligent pens; begs for a letter if only a line.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Offers his services; does not wish to quit his present soild establishment until he knows what conditions he may expect; his former military services; well known to any officer in the Irish regiment in France; a great friend of Gen. Conway.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends by the Continental ship Ranger the articles of capitulation with Mr. Burgoyne and a copy of a letter written by Gen. Gates to Burgoyne six days before the surrender; had the happiness to be a witness of this scene. Magnificent conduct of Gen. Gates. Howe's army in possession of Philadelphia; his situation thought to be almost as bad as Burgoyne's. Description of the retreat of the English, the horrible scenes of death and destruction and the final glorious surrender of the entire army.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Congratulating him on the grand events in America; what the Americans owe to Franklin's influence and counsels. His uncle, Col. Josiah Quincy, prevented from writing Franklin by the danger of the times. By the impolicy of Britain the militia of America have become disciplined troops. Britain's perilous situation. His son serving with Capt. Jones on the Ranger; if Capt. Jones should promote him, would be obliged for Franklin's support; sure the family of the wendells and Quineys are not disagreeable to him. Mentions Capt. Jones as a sensible, well-bred gentleman, who has the honor of America much at heart.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing Lieut. Thomas Simpson of the Ranger, a most distinguished officer.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing Mr. Jonathan Loring Austin to Franklin's favorable notice. Congratulates him on the success of the American arms in the Northern Department; news from the southward not discouraging; Gen. Howe and his army said to be preparing for a retreat from Philadelphia; Washington at or about Germantown waiting to cut him off. Wishes to know what effect Gates's success will have on England and also on the Courts of Europe.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A manufacturer of materials for soldiers' and sailors' uniforms desires to send a cargo of these goods to New England; failure of a previous attempt owing to capture; is the owner of a well-appointed vessel; desires Franklin to furnish him with letters of marque that he may carry this merchandise safely across. Served some months under Capt. Wickes.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His favor of the 25th inst. he immediately destroyed. Certain debts which he must pay. Question of putting arms on board the Lion.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The demand of the Dutch merchants accorded. Believes his services can be of some use to America; risk involved in his present position; depends on him to hear as soon as possible of the success of their scheme.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing M. le Chevalier du Gravier, a friend of M. Coder and an officer of artillery, also M. de Livoys, navy officer, actually in the service of America. Enmity of M. des Granges and all his employes toward Coder.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing M. St. Godet, son-in-law of the Governor of St. Eustatius; he is interested in all that is most dear to Franklin.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begs for the papers he mentioned to Franklin, namely: Count Vergennes's letter, the last memoir to him, the last letter to the Committee and the list of stores shipped from Marseilles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Very interesting business calls him and two of his friends to Philadelphia; being unable to pay their passage thither, begs Franklin to procure it for them.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires to know from what source he can gain some information concerning the habits of the colonies, principally of the Quakers and the savages; these details are necessary for a work he is contemplating.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging Franklin's letter and promising that everything shall be executed according to his wishes. Sends message to Mr. Deane.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: He and two others very anxious to join la Fayette; desires Franklin's advice and assistance to attain this end; asks for a letter from Madame de la Fayette, who is at present in Paris.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Prizes given to the English by special order of the King; money loss less serious than the excuse this will give to spies to live among them.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acquainting Franklin with the fact that Miss Lydia B[ache] and her sister, of Preston, have lost their mother, and asking him to break the news gently to R[ichard] B[ache].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Madame le Baronne de la Courchambeau desires her two sons to enter the service of Congress and will make them a certain allowance and pay their passage over; begs Franklin to aid them in this affair with letters to some one in Congress.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: In difficulties about his agreement with M. de Purny; desires to sail in the service of his own country; asking for Franklin's advice.

did.physdesc: A.L.S. Richard Henry Lee and James Lovell. 1p.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: The Continental Congress, Committee of Foreign Affairs. York, Pa

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Bills of exchange to be presented with this letter. Henry Laurens, of Charleston, South Carolina, has been elected President of the Continental Congress.
(In duplicate.)

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Diplom. Corres., Wharton, II, 423.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Instructions to the American Commissioners in France and Spain, to purchase military supplies.

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Journals of Congress, Phila. [1778], III, 488.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Switzerland's attitude concerning the misfortunes of England and America; possibility of a reconciliation through the medium of a just, equitable, pacifying mediator.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Parliament not to meet until more explicit accounts are received from Lord Howe; influence this will have on the case of poor Platt still confined in Newgate with others of his countrymen. Begs Franklin not to suffer Lord Stormont or any of his tools to prevent the exchange of prisoners proposed. Many young men ready to serve in the American army; mortified at not receiving a line from any of her countrymen in Paris.

did.unittitle: to The Congress of the United States.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: de Lucé, Chevalier de Marolles. Paris

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Offers his services; encloses certificates of his capacity.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning the orders of the French Government to hand over the prizes to the English; cannot reconcile such proceedings with common honesty; begs to know whether there is a prospect of his getting his advances repaid. Praise for Capt. Nicholson.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires some position connected with the commerce between America and Italy.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing a copy of a letter from St. Eustatius with news from America of the taking of Philadelphia by Howe; this account founded merely on reports. Should Washington have been again repulsed, thinks his army could not have behaved with that bravery which should have distinguished troops in such an important situation; what this event, if true, will mean to the English. Gen. Gate's operations in Canada.
[Letter enclosed.]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Announcing the taking of Philadelphia by Howe; the position of Washington at Germantown; Gen. Gates's movements against Burgoyne.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begging Franklin to accord a moment's audience to M. Henri du Bois, a merchant of Amsterdam, who has affairs of interest to communicate. Sends Franklin an ode and introduces the author of it, M. Courtney Melmoth.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires to go back to New England; begs him to endorse his commissions, which have doubtless been presented by M. le Comte d'Ossun. Delay in setting out due to his father's death; begs Franklin to give him letters for his superior officers that he may justify his lengthened absence.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His promise of letters of recommendation on behalf of a young gentleman, who has been too ill to avail himself of them; begs them for two brothers, the Messrs, Poullain; the elder an advocate in the Parliament of Paris, who desires to become a planter; the younger an officer in the King's service, who desires a position in the Light Troops. Remembers Franklin's kindness to him when detained a prisoner of war in Philadelphia; reasons for granting his request.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Informing Franklin of the death of Madam Bache, his daughter's mother-in law; offers to be a medium for Franklin's correspondence with M. Theobald and his other friends.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sympathy for America. Desires to get a position as housekeeper. Kindness shown to her by Franklin's friends, Mr. and Mrs. Walker; asked their interest for her son, Sammy, to get him promoted from a midship man to lieutenant; begs Franklin to write Mr. Walker in his favor.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A company of merchants is forming in Zealand to trade directly with America. Rumor that the Grand Pensionnaire of Amsterdam is incensed against the English. Anecdote concerning one of his late pupils and Sir Joseph Yorke. Sends the Leyden Gazette with the article quoted from the Marryland paper concerning R. H. Lec.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning the construction of certain packets whose object will be to carry despatches back and forth at regular intervals; they will offer their services to Congress if they wish to entrust their mail to them; makes the same offer to Franklin. His attachment to the cause of America, and to Franklin in particular.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning a passage for the Count d'Attems and the payment of his expenses until he embarks.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has the honor to present him with the enclosed memoir; M. Dalibard would have been the bearer himself but the affair was too pressing; begs for a word in reply that he may inform his son of Franklin's decision.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks for information concerning the use of tobacco ashes as a cure for dropsical complaints.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Writes for a prescription, said to be given by Franklin, for the cure of dropsy. Sent him a packet of newspapers with accounts of all the news in London.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is a merchant of Auray in Brittany, petitions for the release of his son and another officer of the ship "Le Fargès" captured by an English squadron.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends Franklin a pamphlet at the request of the author. Various electrical experiments. Certain theories concerning waterspouts.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: A.M. Hevin de Navarre and Francois Antoine, Baron de Seyffertit. Wurtzbourg

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Request for money to pay their expenses to Paris and return, to be able to tell Franklin their plans for military service in America.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Directing the Commissioners of the United States, at the several Courts of Europe, to deny the report that a treaty had been concluded with Great Britain.
In duplicate.

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Journals of Congress, Phila. [1778], III, 527.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desiring a brief audience.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Congratulating them on the safe arrival, at Nantes, of the Amphitrite. Understands that the King of P[russia] has refused passage to English troops en route to America. Certainty of a war between Russia and Turkey. Second letter on English credit to be printed at once. Account of a conversation he had with a great lady, a friend of Sir Joseph Yorke, concerning the latter's irritation against him for his espousal of the American cause. Information received which leads him to believe that the United States could obtain men, for their army and navy, more cheaply from Poland than any other nation. Has translated the extracts for Mr. Lee and sent him the various gazettes.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: T. and N. Eckhardt. The Hague

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking Franklin to subscribe to a work containing a description of an instrument invented by them. Encloses a memoir on the capstan, a marvelous invention; also begs his acceptance of a new fabric of their own make. A statement of the advantages of the capstan.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: La Rochefoucauld, Louis-Alexandre duc de La Roche-Guyon et de. La Rocheguyon

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Heard with pleasure of the arrival of the Amphitrite with the good news. The King of England, in his harangue, seems to consider the American war as difficult, but not impossible, if Parliament will grant him large subsidies; likens him to La Fontaine's fable of "The Serpent and the File." Certain ideas on the circulation of air. Impatient to see Franklin and render him the homage of his veneration and attachment.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Applies to Franklin on behalf of a young man who desires a lieutenancy in the American army.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Congratulates them on the glorious success of the army under General Gates. General Howe said to be making his retreat towards Wilmington to embark on his transports, and that several frigates have been sunk or destroyed in endeavoring to raise the chevaux de frise in the Delaware. Impossible to foretell the effect of this important intelligence on the politics of Europe. Hopes that the Court of France may be influenced by it to take a more decisive part in our favor. The orders of the Ministry in regard to American privateers and prizes and the restriction of American trade have lately been notified to the Chamber of Commerce here, and their execution enacted under great penalties, but he does not believe they will be enforced with any degree of rigor. Thinks it is only a political stroke. The arrival of the troops destined for these islands, and the Spanish galleon in Spain are the real motives for retarding their hostile operations. The troops have arrived and he is informed that the galleon is to sail in the beginning of December, and that the specie, amounting to fifteen million Sterling, has been deposited on board twenty-two ships of the line.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Copy of letter, VII, 106, with an added note that General Howe is retreating and Washington is in quiet possession of Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desired by Messrs. Fairholme and Luther, of St. Martin, to forward this enclosed letter.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The agrecable news of General Burgoyne's surrender with his entire army; for all the particulars, refers them to Mr. Austin.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires to dedicate, to Franklin, a small volume of verse, entitled, "II Washington"; the subject is the present war but so handled as to be favorable to America and at the same time to give no offense to England.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Petition of a French officer in the American service who was taken prisoner by the English at Fort Washington.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has just learned, from Franklin's son, the good news from America about the surrender of General Burgoyne and his troops. Wanted to go immediately to congratulate Franklin in person. Is going to compose a march of triumph.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Congratulates Franklin on the defeat and capture of Burgoyne. The news caused a great sensation here in Brussels. Hopes Howe will soon be defeated by Washington and that Lee will regain his liberty.
(In French.)

did.physdesc: L.S. Rich[ar]d Henry Lee, James Lovell. 4p.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: The Continental Congress, Committee of Foreign Affairs. York, Pa

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Return to France of the dissatisfied French officers. Their unreasonable demands in America.
(Copy.)

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Diplom. Corres., Wharton, 11, 437.

did.physdesc: A.L.S. Rich[ar]d Henry Lee, James Lovell. 8p.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: The Continental Congress, Committee of Foreign Affairs. York, Pa

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Summary of the military events of the campaigns just closing. Civil affairs Lifeless condition of commerce owing to British watchfulness. More American ships needed.

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Diplom. Corres., Wharton, II, 438.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Raves of his devotion to liberty and his intense interest in the present struggle. Wishes Franklin to procure him some position in America, either civil or military.
(In Latin and French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Question of detaining Captain Young until the arrival of the despatches or sending him off without them.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires the enclosed letter to be delivered to the Minister of Marine; angry at the treatment he and his men have received; insolence of the Commissary at l'Orient; attitude of France in playing this fast and loose game; the inevitable delay none of his doing.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: At his arrival in the Capital found the Court was gone to Villa-Vicoza; followed and delivered Franklin's memorial to the Minister, enforcing it with all the reasons he could think of; awaits an answer; will do all in his power to bring this negotiation to a favorable conclusion.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has received no answer to his letter of October 28th; repeats the contents of this letter.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Announcing his arrival in the Ranger, having taken two brigantines from Malaga laden with fruit for London; met with few opportunities of making captures; repairs wanted on the Ranger. Affairs in America in the most promising condition.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Brandeis, near Prague, Bohemia. Wishes to enter the American army.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The bearer is Mr. David, the Elector Palatine's Secretary of the Embassy. Cannot, in a letter, enter into the result of his private inquiries, made in Switzerland and at the Courts of Baden and Mannheim, as to the possibility of their intercession with the King of England in favor of the Colonies, all the Europe cries shame on Great Britain; advisability of some trusted person high in the King's opinion, such as M. du Luc, broaching the subject to him privately; quotes precedents to prove this method a successful one. Concerning the preliminary concessions to be made on both sides.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begging Messrs. Franklin, Deane and Lee to name an hour when he may wait upon them.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Their ship bound for Virginia with a cargo of salt; their pilot is Mr. Joseph Price, from Philadelphia, who is returning to America after being a prisoner in England for six months. Desires to know the signals to be used off the coast of America; unknown to Franklin but sends references.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reminds Franklin that his letters to Messrs. La Goaner, of Corunna, were to be sent under his cover, for fear of interception; uneasy on account of Franklin's silence; begs to know if he has written direct or not at all.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begging Franklin to write M. Duparny to supply him with the money he promised; desires to be paid from the time of his engagement and receive two months' advance.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sailed from Philadelphia in February as first lieutenant on board the Hornet, a Continental sloop commanded by John Nicholson, Esq., now in Forton prison; he made his escape from prison with five others; treated with great kindness by Mr. Johnston, in London, who paid his expenses to Dunkirk; since his arrival has received no more attention than if he were a common sailor; his destitute condition; applies to Franklin for aid.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Unless they can obtain the repcal of certain orders lately issued by the Ministry, none of the vessels at present loading, can sail. Concerning the management of ships of war, prizes etc; empowered by Mr.Morris to act in these matters at his agent; explains his reasons for consenting to this arrangement.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Question of a certain bill being accepted. Has sent the pipe of sherry wine.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Congratulating him on the success of the Americans; lays before Franklin the enclosed memoir at the request of one of his friends.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Had the honor of writing Franklin, on October 15th, requesting orders from Congress for linen and cotton fabrics. [See VII, 72.] Repeats the details given in that letter.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has some affairs which demand her immediate return to England; danger of seeing or corresponding with her American friends in Paris, owing to the suspension of the Habeas Corpus Act; feels sure her imprisonment would greatly distress Franklin; would sacrifice her life to be of any real use to the cause of liberty; at present is nursing her constitution to be able to write the civil wars.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning the aid they have given to Americans, and the money due them for such disbursements. Prices to tobacco and rice.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Recommending Mr. Flower to Franklin; he knows the art of making a powder to stop the blood.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Congratulating him on the success of the American arms; trusts they will continue their victories; sends a bust of Franklin to his grandson; desires that no one may be allowed to copy it.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Interested in the defense of American vessels; hopes it is not an indiscretion to ask news of the fate of their arms; the newspapers give only contradictory reports.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: M. de Reveaux de St. Varran and three of his brothers desire to pass into the service of Congress; will, himself, be responsible for their conduct and talents; being of an ancient, but unfortunate family, they have no money to pay their passage; asks Franklin if he could procure it for them.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: La Bedoyère, Marie Corantin, marquis de. Rennes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking for a place in the American service, for a young man in whom he has a particular interest; his rank, qualities and experience fit him to be a good sailor or soldier; wishes information as to the port he must sail from, the vessel, etc.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Ten thousand blankets ready to be shipped from Bilboa together with a quantity of naval equipments; desires to know whether he may order M. Gardoqui to purchase ships for these articles or freight them at once; question of payment; secrecy and expedition shown by M. Gardoqui.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Franklin is never long out of his thoughts; hopes to see him once more. Sympathy for America; thinks the war cannot be continued without disgrace and ruin. Sends two volumes of his on metaphysics; hopes he has received his third volume on air.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sailed fron Bilboa, with his poor naked crew, by favor of M. Gardoqui who trusted him with £100 Sterling. Account of the capture of six fishing vessels from Newfoundland.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His position as editor of the Utrecht Gazette; his sympathies with the Americans; desires to publish prompt and authentic news; difficulty of obtaining accurate reports; applies to Franklin to procure him a correspondent for his paper who can furnish news from America. Congratulates him on their victory over Burgoyne.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His military career; asks for the conditions for entering the American service.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begs Franklin to help him to procure a free passage to the United States and employment there.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging Franklin's favor of the 2d inst. along with the dispatches for Congress, which he will secure ready for sinking in case of danger. Information received of seven sail of English cruisers off Belle Isle; will remain in port until further tidings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Expressing his keen appreciation of Franklin's kindness in signing himself his "affectionate friend," and thanking him warmly for the letters of recommendation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has seen Sir George Grand. Begs Franklin to make his excuses to Count Maillebois as he is too pressed with business to go out that afternoon, and tell him that he has not forgotten the case of M. de la Brosse. Desires Franklin and M. Chaumont to call on him on their return from dinner.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Expressing his sincere appreciation of Franklin's "Constitution of Pennsylvania"; in reading it, thought of several points which he wrote down and sends herewith.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanking him for his kind letter in favor of Mr. Platt who is most grateful for Franklin's offer; a worthy man has paid the money to Mr. Platt and accepted a bill on Franklin.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Ingratitude he has met with for his past services; reasons for remaining in Dunkirk after receiving Franklin's remittance; obliged to give his clothes to Captain Cunningham's deserters for fear of worse consequences should he refuse; can neither go back nor forward unless Franklin helps him.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: A.Y. Ameloo, P. Wittentrin and F. and A. Dubbeldemutt. London

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning the ship Chester and her cargo; no one has the least interest in her except the Republic of Holland; begs Franklin to name some one in Charleston to care for their interests; begs for the restitution and compensation due them by incontestable right.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begging Franklin to see to the safe delivery of a letter she has written to her son in America.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His promise to give him letters of introduction to Congress, and to gentlemen of consequence at Charlestown and other cities; their intention to fix themselves at Charlestown as general merchants; propriety of keeping their design secret.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Request for authority to form a regiment for service in the United States.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requests a commission in the American army.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning the quarto bibles wanted for America. Hears that the gentleman who brought the news of Burgoyne's surrender intends to go to England; rashness of this project. Account of a visit from Dr. Ingen Housz. His earnest wishes for the establishment of liberty and peace.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: MacMahon, John. At the Military school in Paris

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The gentlemen of this house all well-wishers to Franklin's cause and delighted with the news of Burgoyne's defeat; opinion of the Prince de Montbarrey; the Commander of the above establishment, M. le Marquis de Tinburne, requests Franklin's company at dinner with his grandson, Mr. Deane or any other friends he thinks proper to bring.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Congratulating Franklin on the defeat of Burgoyne; hopes to hear soon of his brother Howe sharing the same fate.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing list of wines for which he begs Franklin's orders. Congratulating him on the victories of the Americans.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has just returned from Paimboeuf where he saw as fine a ship as any in the navy. Expects to see Captain Nicholson and if the obstacles are removed, will soon finish the expedition.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Describes the ship, Duras, a great bargain but old and in sad need of repairs; discusses the advisability of purchasing her.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His ship destined for Maryland or Virginia; begs Franklin to accord his captain letters of recommendation as he knows no one in that part of America.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has lately returned from Congress. Sums up the successes of the American arms; general opinion that Howe's safety depends on his flight; strictness of blockade around Philadelphia where horses are being killed for food. News just received of the capture, by the Americans, of the Syren and two transports off Rhode Island. Georgia in the tolerable state of defense; plundering war carried on by their neighbors in Florida.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning a powder mill which he desires to erect according to a new plan of construction, a sketch of which he encloses; applies to Franklin, as one of the greatest philosophers and mechanics, for his advice; would offer his services to Congress were he not old and fatigued with many campaigns.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Her son sailed in April with the Marquis de Lafayette; begs Franklin not to lose sight of him.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Writes on behalf of the orphan son of Mr. Huske whom he once served as the valet de chambre; his apprenticeship to Mr. Hooper, of Wilmington, nearly expired; begs Franklin to recommend the young man to some one of his friends in that part of the world.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Lefebure, Marquis. St. Valery sur Somme

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Very uneasy about the bark, Le Dillon, and the captain, François Lefebure, his son; she was captured on July 24th by an American and taken, it was said, to Boston; has had no further news; begs Franklin to give him some information of the matter, if possible.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begging for news of the fate of M. le Chevalier Du Coudray; ties of friendship and relationship make him hope that the public rumors may not be confirmed.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The bearer is Mr. Geo. Searle, who has advanced the twenty guineas for her bill on Franklin, drawn for the use of Mr. Platt.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending a deposition made by Captain Benet, who was lately taken by the English at the entrance of the river.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanking Franklin for his valuable present to his son; hopes now that he possesses an impression of Franklin's person, he will study to imitate his conduct. Misplaced confidence shown by the legislative and executive powers in the present ministers; Lord Chatham's views on this subject, as shown by his motion for a cessation of war and a recall of the troops; he and Lord Camden send their best compliments.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanking Franklin for the flattering letter he has been kind enough to give him; begs that he will join to it an order for a free passage; M. Delap, at Bordeaux, the person to write to; his desires to sail at once.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking Franklin to take charge of the enclosed letter to his friend, M. de la Fayette.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Use of tobacco ashes in dropsy; desires to know the dose and the method of administering it. His enthusiastic partisanship of the American cause.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Recommending Mr. Roegler; his reputation as a scholar at the University of Leipzig.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Baudouin, ------ Secretary to M. de Sartine. Paris

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has received the letter Franklin sent; will translate and send it to M. de Sartine by his courier.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Every matter concerning the Raleigh transacted by M. Bérard to his entire satisfaction; the port of L'Orient a safe harbor and easy of access.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His former military services; desires to know how he can reach the headquarters of General Washington, and if, on his arrival, he will be sure to get a position as Major.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Embarked on a Dutch ship bound for Boston with Franklin's letter of recommendation to General Washington; was taken prisoner and brought to Portsmouth; suffered all kinds of bad treatment from the English; his destitute condition; begs Franklin to write a line in his favor to Mr. Benjamin Vaughan, of London, who will then procure him the means of realizing his former intentions.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing a letter for Franklin from Amsterdam and asking Franklin to give the bearer the promised letter of recommendation.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Lacepède, Bernard-Germain-Etienne de La Ville-sur-Illon, comte de. Paris

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning certain experiments which he invites Franklin to witness.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Congratulates him on the victories in America, and requests a commission in the American army.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: De Norey, Jean Louis Destelan. Rennes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Account of his services and request for a commission in the American navy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Veneration Germans have for the heroic deeds of General Arnold. Is he the son of a Mayence butcher? Was he a monk of the order of St. Francis? Arnold wrote to Mayence in 1773. Received papal dispensation recently. Thinks General Arnold is his son. A copper print of Arnold, made in London, in 1776, and sold in Mayence, confirms his belief. Others assert that General Arnold was born in New England.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requesting another letter of credit on M. Grand.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has been entirely undeceived with respect to his brother; being unable to defend him longer, is determined to give him up entirely to his own fate; apologizes profusely to Dr. Franklin and Mr. Deane for his conduct in this affair; his error founded on misinformation.
(In duplicate.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanking Franklin for relieving his sufferings; in case of an exchange, begs that he may be included therein.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Offering their services as dealers in glass-ware asking for the usual measure of window glass in America.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Still another proof of his customary bad luck; sailed for America July 18th; arrived at Charlestown; received a sum of money from the Committee of Carolina to enable him and the other members of the corps to join General Washington; captured on the way by two English frigates; held as prisoners in St. Augustine, Florida; privations and miseries; their united desire to return home; begs Franklin to narrate these facts to anyone who takes an interest in his fate.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Encloses a letter and begs Franklin to send the answer to his care.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begs Franklin to intercede for him, a carmelite friar, with Father Gautier, in Paris, and to ask that his failings be condoned.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing Comte de Rostaing a general officer of artillery and a man of great worth. Great victories obtained in America. Reminds Franklin of his promise to give his son an introduction to the Bishop of St. Asaph.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Deux-Ponts, Marianne Camasse, duchesse La douairière de

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requests a commission in the American army, for her nephew, M. de Fontevieux.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Recommending a friend who wishes to enter the American service.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A request to enter the American army.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begging Franklin to send, by bearer, the letters of recommendation he promised them.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Informing him that the two frigates of Congress, the Raleigh and the Alfred sailed that afternoon, accompanied by the King's frigate which had orders to render them every assistance; during their stay, neglected no opportunity of being useful to them. Arrival of Mr. Moylan.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Departure of the Raleigh and Alfred, accompanied by a French sloop of war; will communicate with him later on the subject of his errand at L'Orient.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begging for news of his son, Antoine-Maximilien-César Le Francq, who enlisted under the American flag.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Believes he is related to the famous general of the same name; begs Franklin to forward the enclosed letter to him containing a copy of his coat of arms; ardently desires to go over to America, should this relationship prove to be true.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: He requests to enter the American army, if in no other way, as a common soldier.
(In French.)

origination.persname: Conway, Françoise-Antoinette-Jeanne Langlois du Bouchet, comtesse de. Auxerre

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Congratulating him on the late successes in America; asks if it is true that Mr. Allen has a letter for her from her husband, the General; good wishes for Franklin and America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: News in the London papers of the evacuation of Mud Island.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Delivered all the letters, except those of Lord North and Sir Grey Cooper.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending his address and requesting that it be given to Mr. Deane.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requests a commission in the army.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Inquiring about her son, Colonel [Charles] Armand [Marquis de la Rouerie], who was serving in the American army under General Gates.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Arrival of Mr. Hodge from Dunkirk; Mr. Deane entreats Dr. Franklin to come to town immediately on business of very great importance.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Gives an extract from a letter written to him by Abbé d' Aydie concerning a young nobleman, M. d' Abzac, who wishes to go to America and serve under La Fayette. Asks if Franklin can give this young man a passport and a letter of recommendation.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Account of how the Board House, at Purflect, was struck by lightning and what damage was done, mostly to the roof of the building. After the accident the lightning rods on the roof were found to have a round copper knob or cap at the top, instead of being sharply pointed as recommended.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desiring to serve in the American army.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Inquires if he has any news of M. de Fleury a French officer in the service of the United States.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is a captain of infantry with rank of licutenant colonel; proposes to bring to America, at his own expense, ten officers, also to fit out a troop to be commanded by these officers. M. de Beaumarchais endorses him.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Offers to supply Congress with flint stones for use by the American troops.
A.E. by Franklin thanking him for his offer and promising to send it to Congress.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends substance of Lord Chatham's motion.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Request to enter the service of America.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has been to see Abbé Rochon who showed him an experiment in electricity with a metal jar on a glass base. Thinks he has found the explanation of the phenomena which takes place in this experiment. Asks Franklin's opinion of his theory.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Urged by one of his friends to recommend to Franklin, de Neuville, a French officer who desires to fight in the army of the insurgents; has a high opinion of the gentleman's bravery, but considers a recommendation of this kind indiscreet and useless.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Proposal for sending weekly packet boats to the United States.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Proposes to furnish uniforms for the American troops. Describes and gives cost of each article, which compares favorably with similar articles supplied to the French troops.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reports on the clothing and equipment proposed for the American troops. Recommends a certain type of uniform and makes several suggestions.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Urges Franklin to accept his proposals to furnish supplies for the American troops and to send skilled workmen to repair and keep the equipments and clothing in good condition. Observations on the political situation in England as viewed with relation to the colonies in America.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Claims that the uniforms and clothing, supplied by him for the American troops, are much superior to those previously supplied by others. Requests Dr. Franklin and Deane not to delay their orders, as otherwise he would be at considerable loss.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning the advisability of sending the material to America and having the uniforms made there rather than pay such exorbitant prices for them in France.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Makes a report to Franklin on the 12,000 rifles which Dubourg and Dalibard propose to furnish to the United States. Approves the model. Suggests a few changes.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Describes different plans for destroying England's commerce on the sea, making raids on the English coast, seizing the channel islands and forcing England to come to terms with the United States. Submitted his plans to M. de Sartine. Deplores that they were not adopted by the latter.
(In French.)

origination.persname: The Compiler of the book "Affaires de l'Amérique"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Recommending a young surgeon to the Deputies of Congress.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Conway, Françoise-Antoinette-Jeanne Langlois du Bouchet, comtesse de. Paris

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Report of a battle in America, six hundred English lost, and General Washington wounded; desires to know whether her husband and brother arrived in time to aid their friends; reminds him of his promise to tell her the news, whether good or ill.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Inquires if Dr. Franklin will be able to come to see him as promised.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has called to see Dr. Franklin. Was acquainted with him in London in 1768 and a frequent visitor to him and Sir John Pringle.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Request to enter the service of America.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Before the express leaves for Nantes, desires to know what sum must be paid Captain Bell.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Advises that a copy of a contract with M. de Chaumont be sent to Mr. Williams and also to the Secret Committee.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending letters, etc., received that evening from London; congratulating him on their important contents. Appointing a time to see him on business, relating in part to Captain Hynson.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing a letter from Mr. Bingham with news of the safe arrival, at Martinique, of the cargo from Havre.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Request to enter the American service.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wishes to see Franklin, in Paris that morning, as early as possible.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Inquiring if Dr. Franklin is going to Versailles and if he could give him a place.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Request for himself and his nephew, Jean Baptiste de Belgarée, to enter the American service.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Petitions for a military appointment in America, where he intends to settle with his family.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires to enter the American army.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanking Franklin for sending her a poetical work entitled the "Vision of Columbus."
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begs Franklin to procure him a passage to America and the rank of officer in the army there.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing M. Michel Rey, bookseller of Amsterdam. Books sent to Franklin; anxious for news of America; prophesies a great future for the country. Admiration for Robertson's histories. (Incomplete.)
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Entrusted by Mr. Sayre with certain letters to be sent by the first two ships bound for America; desires to know when the next ship will sail.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Request to enter the American service.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks Dr. Franklin's assistance to obtain the release of his ship from Dunkirk.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Request to enter the American army.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desiring, with several of his friends, to serve in the American army.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Announcing the arrival of an express at Lord Stormont's with news of an American defeat on October 24th.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending a new translation of Richard, lent by M. Quétant. Will let him know as soon as his cannon are in prime condition.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking Franklin to accept a gift of some story books which may amuse his grandchildren.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Offers his services to the United States if given the rank of Major General; would raise and train a regiment of dragoons in America to serve during the war with England. Describes how they should be armed and equipped.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Offering to supply him with all the information concerning their family and their possible relationship.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Was to have sailed as an officer with M. Du Coudray for America. Could not reach Havre in time. Wishes to be included in the list of officers enrolled by M. Du Coudray and be given the means to leave for America without delay.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Proposes, to Franklin, to send the list of articles which Congress needs to Holland to get the prices thereof for comparison.
(In French).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing a warning against a man in Morlaix called Walker. Invitation to dine with him the following day.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Inquiring at what hour he can get Franklin's instructions for Versailles and if the latter could lend him his carriage.
(In French).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Will wait on Franklin to learn if he has any commands as he leaves Paris Sunday.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Offering to supply America with arms.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Promising to deliver Franklin's dispatches in Philadelphia, or to destroy them, should he fall into the hands of the piratical cruizers of Britain.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking for news of his brother who was reported to have sailed for America.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Writes from America where he is erecting batteries and fortifying certain points on the coast. Deplores the lack of unity and activity amongst the Americans. Are averse to making any defensive preparations requiring labor until the enemy is upon them. Explains the difficulties he has to contend with; engineering skill not appreciated. Learned with regret of M. de Woedtke's death in Canada. Solicits promotion to the latter's rank so as to have the right to take part in the Councils of War.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Petition concerning his son, Jean Rousseaux, who was taken prisoner on the brig Lexington after a battle with English warships.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Military history; requests to enter the American service.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desiring confirmation of her good news from America. Enclosing a letter for a poor prisoner from his mother; begs that it may be forwarded safely. Wishes to know the first favorable opportunity for sending letters to her husband.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Induced by Captain de la Plaigne to enlist in a corps for service in the United States. Captured by an English privateer at sea. Lost all his money and effects. Appeals to Franklin for assistance.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is captain in the 1st Georgia regiment; sent to France by the State of Georgia on a military mission; petitions the American Commissioners to indemnify him, and his companions, for losses incurred through their capture by an English privateer and imprisonment in England.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking the exact date Franklin expects them all for dinner. Sends the last proof of his memoir on the form to be given to conductors; desires Franklin's observations thereupon.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Inquires about Franklin's cold and hopes that Mr. Deane is better.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Gives his qualifications and request to go to the United States.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requests a grant of land in one of the provinces of South America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Request to enter the service of the United States.

scopecontent.p: Request to enter the army.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

(In French.)

(In French.)
