scopecontent.p: A begging letter from an Irish Franciscan friar.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Circumstantial account of the prize "Portsmouth" captured by the Swallow; expects to be censured as the owner of this vessel; is in no way responsible for the affair.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The record of his campaigns.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wishes to enter the American service.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Explains the straits to which he and his family have been reduced by the pillage of his plantations near Boston and Charlestown by both armies in America. Begs Franklin to help him secure possession of his property.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: De la Mothe, François Henry Hervée

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Statement of his military career.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Request to enter the American service.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning his mercantile affairs; desires Franklin's kind interference on his behalf.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Captain Pock, of the Ship Benjamin

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Applies for permission to arm and fit out his vessel as a privateer to wage war on English shipping.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Gives his qualifications and requests a commission in the army.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Request to enter the army.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends a letter from Abbé Bandeau. Offers to raise a corps of troops and seize the Zafarimes Islands for the United States and to wage war on English shipping.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His capture on the frigate "Lexington," and arrival in France, destitute of everything; applies for aid.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Excusing himself and M. Penet from dining with him owing to a previous engagement.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Gives his war record and copies of nine letters from different persons about him.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: de St. Jean, Sieur de Barre

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks for a commission of lieutenant-colonel in the army.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Chevalier Villepré sailing for America to serve as Lieutenant-colonel in the service of the United States; asks permission for his nephew to accompany him.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is a surgeon of the Salpétriere Hospital at Paris; offers his services to the United States.
(In French, In duplicate.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Offers to produce in the United States, and furnish to the Government all the saltpetre it may need to make powder.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending copies of the letters patent granted to the Royal Society of Medicine, also a list of its members; desiring his presence at the next meeting of the Society.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Request to enter the service of the United States.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Inviting Messrs. Franklin, Deane and Lee to dine with him.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is Licutenant-Colonel of Engineers in the service of the United States; taken prisoner on the fall of Fort Washington and confined in Forton prison in England.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Jean Conrad Zollicoffer, formerly with Schweighauser of Nantes, is going to Philadelphia to begin business. Asks him to recommend him to some people there.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Recommending an officer of artillery who wishes to go to America to seek a career there.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Memorandum giving names of two French firms who could supply flour, clothing, etc.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has been requested, by the Marquis of Courtauvaux, to speak to Franklin about another artillery officer who is as highly recommended as M. Mauduir Duplessis. Asks if it would be profitable to send silk and other fabrics made at Lyons and Tours to North America.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: "Epistle to the United States and to Franklin". Poem.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: "To Dr. Franklin delegate from the United Provinces of America" and " to General Washington". Poem.
(In Latin.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: "Epistle to the Insurgents". Verses.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: On King George and pointed and blunt lightning conductors. Verses.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: With reference to a proposed agreement between a Company in France and the United States Congress for the sale of tobacco to the former.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A plan for secretly attacking and setting fire to the Englsih fleet in New York Harbor.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Proposal to sell a newly built frigate mounted with thirty-six guns.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Petition from unknown against ----- Penet, agent for the State of Virginia.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Outline of a project for raising, in the name of the King of France, a Regiment of Foreigners to be employed as auxiliaries in the service of the United States of America.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: List of stores on board of the privateer "Dolphin".

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Giving particulars of cannon which have been delivered at Havre and Dunkerque.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requests that Chevalier de la Mothe be put at the head of the Engineers because of his great experience and that he be allowed 10,000 livres for his expenses.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A young man asking to serve in America.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks him, on behalf of a Boston printer, whether type for printing English and printing ink can be purchased in France.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: M. de Gimat, who went to America with Lafayette, has been appointed Captain in the Regiment de Viennois at Martinique.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Advice about business transactions with foreigners.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Charged by a number of persons to offer him and General Washington the homage of their admiration. If among the manufacturers of Languedoc any article would be useful to Franklin, they will execute his orders gratis; begs in return for a portrait of General Washington.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: In Paris a whole month and has not yet seen Franklin; expresses an enthusiastic attachment to him; will always glory in having such "a papa" as Franklin; invites him to dine with her father, the Comte de Milly.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends New Year greetings.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desiring a little conversation with him that evening or the next; the gout prevents his leaving the house.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wishing them all good wishes for the New Year. (In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: de Lucé, Chevalier de Marolles. Paris

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Congratulating him on the reported surrender of General Howe. Hopes Franklin will soon receive word from Congress respecting the offer of his services as Captain of Engineers.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requests the Commissioners, from the United States, to assist several American prisoners detained at Dinan, Mayenne, etc., and obtain their release.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Not content with his position; wishes a commission in the American army.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The credit he received from the Commissioners on the public banker is exhausted; desires further instruction.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requesting interviews for two persons; the one desires to go to America on the saltpetre and power scheme; the other, a person who has been imprisoned in London for trading in the American service, and who has just lost a large cargo of tobacco, but is ready to venture forth again.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desiring to know whether he is to accept certain proposals of M. Gourlade or procure a different connection; necessity of having a letter from Franklin addressed to the captains of vessels from America with certain instructions.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is at work on a periodical encyclopaedia, for which a universal correspondence is necessary; Franklin's reputation as the most amiable, the wisest of men; applies to him, therefore, to furnish some political reflections, etc.
(In French)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reflections induced by having seen certain intended reforms of the penal laws in "The Constitution of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Determined to emigrate to America with his family, in spite of his proposition having been refused; asks numerous questions about the country.
(In French. Final part missing.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: MacMahon, John. At the Military school in Paris

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing news received from the Chevalier de Keralio. Notwithstanding all the boasting of Lord Sandwich, he has not chased the American privateers from the coast of Europe.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing Mr. Bradford whose father is the agent for continental prizes in Boston. The rapid depreciation of paper money their greatest difficulty.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking Franklin to appoint an hour when he may call.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing a letter for Mr. Nathaniel Seidel, in Bethlehem, which, if Franklin approves, he desires sent on.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Brig "Grecieux" captured by him; refutes the report that an insult was thereby given to the French Flag.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: MacMahon, John. At the Military school in Paris

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing an invitation from the Duchesses de Mortemart for Franklin and his son to dinner. Report of the English having taken Mud Island, and having had seventy of their officers wounded; put the garrison of four hundred men to the sword.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Presses upon him to devise the means whereby and honorable negotiation may be opened between Great Britain and America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has written many letters, but has received no answer to his offers; his interest in the Colonies.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Extract from a dispatch of the Comte de Degenfeld, Dutch Minister at Vienna, and a copy of a note from the Prince de Kaunitz, concerning the termination of the differences between the Austrian and Palatine Courts. Publication in the London Evening Post of a pretended Resolution of Congress of December 30th, 1776; desires to know if there is any truth in it; in the same paper, read with admiration their letter to Lord North with his pitiable reply.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanking Franklin for certain letters of introduction; his desire to render himself in some manner useful to them.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His tenth letter to Franklin but has not received a line of response; his earnest desire to enter the service of America.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Applies to Franklin for details of the new remedy, tobacco ashes.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning the schooner Hawk's prize Britannia, which was seized by the Marquis de Basecourt, General of St. Sebastian, with a design of confiscation on a spurious pretense of piracy, the vessel unrigged, the cargo unloaded and disposed of, and the crew confined in prison; entreats Franklin's intercession.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Indignant that the despatches to Congress are to be sent under the care of Mr. Carmichael; with Deane's and Franklin's sanction, had promised them to Mr. Stevenson; this promise is flatly contradicted in a letter written to Mr. Stevenson by the Commissioners; objects to being kept in the dark and resents the deepest insult that can be offered a gentleman:—a direct and unjust impeachment of his veracity.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The ships, Duras, for sale at L'Orient, would be a cheap purchase; suggestions in case she is bought. News of Captain Butler of the privateer ship Molly who left Boston November 15th; took four prizes and is headed for some port in Spain.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A friend of America; has a strong desire to adopt that country for his own; law is his profession; desires Franklin's advice as to how he could best invest his money.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Offering his services to the Americans as a physician, provided some fixed salary be assured him.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Congratulating him on the capture of Burgoyne; angry with the American Council for not scalping him. Hurt at M. Morand's mention of him in the former's stuff about pit-coal; encloses letters on the subject. Will soon have his "Art of Watch and Clock Making" in print; will send it when finished. Rails against the tyranny of England and enthuses over the defenders of liberty.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: MacMahon, John. At the Military school in Paris

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends another paper of American news; the sea fight between the privateers seems true; very diffierent accounts given by the English frigate. Expects to dine with him at the Duchesse de Mortemart's.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requesting to know if any resolve of Congress has been passed in the state of Virginia, which would require a person who has property there to return after a certain time or forfeit his rights to it. Reasons why he has been detained in Europe; his devotion to the American cause; only came over to serve his country.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: England will listen to no intercession. Congratulates him on the successes in America. His plan for establishing a public bank in France impracticable. Has to retrieve his private fortune which has been much impaired during his ten years' public services. Sends Franklin an electrical pistol which discharges inflammable air with great force.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: M. Dubourg and M. Jeuneux very anxious for Franklin to inspect some electrical instruments.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begging Franklin to honor him with his orders for arms.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing the Lieutenant-General of the Presidial of La Flêche, where for the last three months he has been working in experimental physics. His pleasure at the success of the American arms.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing the Gazette Extraordinary which gives an account of the evacuation of Mud Island and Red Bank; expects news of great importance from the tenor of Howe's letter.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Request for employment in Boston.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: De Baris, Lt General Forget. Burgonville

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introduces Monsieur Gillot, of German Lorraine, who wishes a commission in the army.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Intends to go to America with his small fortune. Asks how to get there, etc.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking for news of his brother, Francois Arnold, who went to America during the war between France and England; afterward remained there as Secretary to the Commissary at Quebec; a soldier of his name is serving in the American army; if it be his brother, desires to join him.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Informing Franklin that he has forwarded him a book entitled " Simlerus de Rebus publicis Helvetiorum."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires to enter the American army.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Recommending M. Esckhout, a young surgeon.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has received no notice of the arrival of the sabres at Nantes, where they were sent at Franklin's request; desires payment for the rifles. Proposition of the manager of a foundry to furnish cannon, etc., or to send his son to America to conduct the business.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires to make other arrangements in case Franklin cannot procure him employment suitable to his rank.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desiring to know if Chevalier Duplessis distinguished himself during the late victories in America in such a manner that he received a present of two horses from Congress in recognition of his bravery; if true, will endeavor to procure "La Croix de St. Louis" for this young man.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is the possessor of some valuable papers dated in the early part of the century concerning the American Colonies; will send them to Franklin and desires his opinion of their value, etc.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sorry that the things to which he objected have been continued in the instructions for Captain Jones; prevented thereby from giving his signature to them except in the manner which he has the honor to send.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Writes for Messrs. de Gonault and Co. Who offer their services to purchase a supply of shirts for America.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Carroll, John. Rock Creek, near Georgetown, Md

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Congratulates Franklin on his health, position and opportunities for meeting interesting people; sees in many ways that Franklin is much in mode in Paris. The feeling in America is that France delays too long. Sad death of M. Pliarne; foul play suspected. News of General Schuyler's family; the treatment of the General universally considered cruel. His friendship and interest in L'Abbé Brotier. Hopes Franklin will soon return to the western world where he will be received with transports.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is the widow of M. de Romas, member of the Academy of Sciences and a worker in electricity. Enclosing a memoir concerning a work of his on the invention of a new rudder for vessels; offers this work to America.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Request, for himself and his brother, to enter the army.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires to go to Boston to fight for America.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Weyl, August Wilhelm. Bonn on the Rhine

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wishes to espouse the American patriots' cause. Is deterred because of unfavorable newspaper reports.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Inquiring about De Gimat, an officer in la Fayette's army.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: With reference to an English family who wish to set up in trade in the United States.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wishes to settle in the United States.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Arrival of two wounded seamen taken in the Lexington. Capture of the brigantine, L'Amiable Reine. News from New York of the defeat of Cornwallis and 6,000 royalists by General Gates; Cornwallis with 1,500 of his men taken prisoner; 900 left dead on the field. German troops descrted and joined the American army. Seventy-six pieces of brass cannon captured by the Continental troops.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing two newspapers brought from Newburyport by the Captain of a small schooner.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Future alliance of France and America. Expects to be in Paris next month when he hopes to embrace Franklin; what America owes to him. His pleasure in the good news from the Colonies marred by the anticipation that Franklin will return to his own country.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begging Franklin to name a time when he may pay him a short visit.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: MacMahon, John. At the Military school in Paris

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His promise to dine with him to meet M. de Bussy, formerly Plenipotentiary Minister at the Court of England. The taking of some French ships, by the English, on the very coast of France must at least rouse the spirit of the Premier.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: The Continental Congress, Committee on Secret Correspondence. Yorktown ,Pa

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The state of military affairs; evacuation of Triconderoga and Mt. Independence; Indians perfectly quiet; General Burgoyne and his troops near Boston; the General will not be suffered to depart until the Convention of Saratoga is ratified by the Court of London; enemy is possession of Rhode Island; respective positions of General Howe and General Washington.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Informed Mr. Beaumarchais that they are ready to account with him for the whole proceeds of the cargo of the Amphitrite; sorry that the accounts of their disbursements for the two frigates exceeded Franklin's expectations; consider Franklin's experessions disagreeable; their disappointment at receiving such treatment.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires that his brethren's settlements on the coasts of Labrador may not be molested by any of the American armed vessels; every year supplies are sent to the missionaries on that coasts, who would starve should the vessel be taken.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending Franklin some introductory letters received from his friends in Virginia. Begs Franklin's assistance in the choice of correspondents and his influence in recommending their firm.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begs for a letter, favorable or otherwise.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has discovered a new way of using gun powder, by which it is possible to fire twelve shots a minute from cannon and with increased velocity and effect. Wishes an interview.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Report brought by a vessel from Baltimore of the capture of New York and Rhode Island by the American troops; this spur needed to enliven the merchants of L'Orient and St. Malo. The ship Duras too old for any profitable purpose.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Request to enter the American service.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Called to congratulate him on the latest events in America; drank his health at the house of his friend M. Le Ray de Chaumont. Invitation from his brother-in-law, le Chevalier O'Gorman, for Franklin to visit him.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires the enclosed letter to be sent to a relative of hers at Salem, M. André Olivier.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Encloses a memoir to be forwarded to Congress if Franklin approves; his desire to become a citizen of Philadelphia.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Hechtfischer, Rev. Erhard Christien. Ickelheim, near Windsheim

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Rejoices at the success of the American arms; his countrymen of Anspach unwilling to fight against the Americans. Desires to emigrate to the United States.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His brother uneasy at receiving no answer to his letter to Franklin written three weeks before, inclosing an important receipt; begs that it may be returned to him at once.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desire on the part of certain iron founders and workmen skilled in every trade, to settle in America, and pursue their various callings; concerning a grant of land and privileges; being Catholics, they wish to know if their religion may be practiced openly.
(In Latin.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Gain de Montagnac, Louis-Laurent-Joseph de. Nevers

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing a prospectus of a history of the Maréchal de Turenne, which he expects to publish shortly; desires to dedicate it to General Washington; wishes to know how many copies he shall retain for the United States.
(In French.)
Dedication and prospectus of a new history of the Maréchal de Turenne. 7p.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Van den Yver and Co. Amsterdam

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires to open a business connection with Franklin.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begging Franklin to revise and certify the enclosed state of facts in order to prevent painful disputes. Color of roots of trees and plants when deprives of light.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking for advice and information on the question of settling in America.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Afraid that the account of the action between General Gates and General Cornwallis was premature; condition of the English in New York. The wounded men from the Lexington given every attention; the cutter which took the Lexington has been captured by an American armed ship.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Report of a proposition made by Lord Chatham for a suspension of arms in America during the winter; question of freedom of trade with various countries.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking that the bearer be given his gold watch; mortified to have inconvenienced Franklin thus.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His ardent desire for reconciliation between Great Britain and America; believes anything short of absolute independence would be practicable.

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Works (Sparks, VIII, 233).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requests to enter the American army.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: He asks permission for his brother, a surgeon, to enter the service of the United States.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends him a copy of his last work, with an impromptu poem, by his wife, addressed to Franklin on his presenting his portrait to a lady.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning, the Article under consideration by the Commissioners as to whether an exemption from duty on molasses is an equivalent for a total exemption of all the exports of North America to the French West Indies; bitterly opposed to the execution of this article; his reasons for this; complains of not having been consulted earlier on this point.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Pressure of business prevented them from informing Franklin of the arrival of Captain Berthelot from New York; enclosing an abstract in French of the Captain's report of that unhappy town.
Abstract of Captain Paul Berthelot's account of affairs in New York.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has sustained the loss of a large fortune; no longer able to support his family with his pen; disappointed in obtaining a secretaryship with the Commissioners; in immediate need of £60; desires Franklin either to put him in the way of earning this sum by writing, or advance it to him as a loan.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Visiting Paris; desires to wait on the ingenious inventor of the "Divine Armonica."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The extraordinary neglect with which he has been treated; forced to complain to Franklin; begs him again to reconsider the Article, which was the subject of his last letter, or at least to make the Treaty for a term of years only.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Stating his objections to the admissibility of the 12th Article concerning the duty upon molasses in the proposed commercial Treaty.

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in R. H. Lee's Life of Arthur Lee, I, 126.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Informed that the Government has ordered 2,000 seamen to be raised in Nantes and 2,500 in St. Malo, besides a number of bakers who are all to proceed at once to Brest; no fishing vessels bound for New Foundland are to be admitted into the seaports.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Regretting their inability to dine with Franklin owing to his sister's late illness, but hopes to have the honor of waiting on him.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Dr. Franklin and Mr. Deane indifferent to his labors. Mrs. Melmoth ill of a fever.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging their letter; will examine the translation.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires to emigrate to America and obtain a position as a masterdyer; wishes to know if this plan is practicable.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning the opening of Mr. Lee's despatches by Mr. Carmichael and the latter's intention of taking the book, in which they were written, to America; Mr. Deane has written for a copy of them. They contain a libel on two of the best men in America.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Millin de la Brosse, Claude-Valentin. Paris

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Urges Franklin and Deane to indemnify him for the losses he incurred whilst serving in the United States as Lieutenant-Colonel and during his imprisonment in England. Offers his services again if reimbursed for his losses.
(In French.) (In duplicate.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Unexpected attack on his character made by Mr. Arthur Lee; gives a detailed account of his conduct since his residence with Mr. Deane; his means of support, etc. Informs Dr. Franklin of the death of Mr. Thoman Morris. Expects to sail in eight days.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing M. Bordot, one of the first victims of England's resentment; his zeal for the American cause; begs Franklin to make him their agent in the town of La Rochelle.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing a note, sent by the Baron Schulenberg, with information of the price of arms in the King of Prussia's manufactory with permission to let the Commissioners have whatever they order.
Note of the Prices of arms. 1p.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging Franklin's letter, in regard to Article 12 of the Treaty of Commerce; afraid it is too late to take notice of Franklin's request to have Articles, 11 and 12 omitted.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Recommending two young men who propose to go to the United States.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Escaped from Mill Prison, England, in company with Captain Eleazer Johnson. Shocking condition of prisoners at Mill Prison.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: The Navy Board of the Eastern Department. Boston

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Bills of exchange for £100 have been drawn upon the Commissioners in favor of William Dennie, of Boston, in order to procure money for John Adams, about to embark to join the Commissioners.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Hopes that he will accord him an answer to his former letter, and at the same time send him the portrait printed on paper of General Washington. Desires to send him a box of truffles, an article celebrated in his Canton.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desiring the loan of two Boston papers and wishing to know if anything has been decided relative to supplying him with the necessary funds for his appointment in Germany.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desired by his friend, D[avid] H[artley], to forward the enclosed letter.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking for information concerning the use of tobacco ashes in dropsical complaints. His method of treating venereal diseases.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: No answer to his or his brother's letter; begs Franklin to return his brother's note and the letter of Congress.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Left the Lion at St. Nazare; has done with both French ships; afraid the Brune will be left. Death of Mr. Morris in his absence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The type is ready to be sent.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His zeal for the American cause; encloses a memoir concerning a new process of making bullets.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sent some time ago a copy of Franklin's Interrogation which he had translated into French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Presenting them with a picture which he has composed, and begging permission to dedicate it to them.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: When Congress sent him a commission for the Court of Tuscany they did not inform him to whom he must apply for money; desires to know if they can furnish him with a letter of credit.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begging Franklin to forward the enclosed letter to his son, an officer [colonel] in the American army.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Accepting an invitation to dine with Franklin provided he can be released from a previous engagement.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begs Franklin's advice and assistance, in procuring from America, various animals and birds, that they may be introduced into France. His desire to visit America; hopes that his only son will take up arms for that country.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Published years before a History of the English settlements in America; the new interest attaching to this subject makes him desirous of remodelling his work and continuing it up to the present time; M. Dubourg has assured him of Franklin's interest and his wish to see the History; encloses a copy.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires information as to some printer or postmaster in America to whom he can apply for a newspaper containing authentic accounts of actions in America.

did.physdesc: L.S. William Ellery, James Forbes, Fra[ncis] Lewis. 1p.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: The Continental Congress, Commercial Committee. York, Pa

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Announcing William Lee's appointment as Commissioner to the Court of Prussia and the removal of Thomas Morris from the Commercial Agency; directed by Congress to desire Franklin to appoint one or more suitable persons as Commercial Agents in France.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: The Continental Congress, Commercial Committee. York, Pa

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The same in duplicate with resolution of Congress.
(Copy.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks for tidings of his son; last news of him was from St. Domingo.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His ill health obliged him to leave Congress for a time. Recommending a young gentleman, Mr. Wm. Vernon, to his particular notice; he desires to enter some mercantile house.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Recommending to Franklin's protection a son of his brother, Silas Deane, who may be absent from Paris when the child arrives; desires that he may be placed in a good school.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The affair of Quiberon in every broker's mouth. Were any continental marine power in Europe disposed to avail themselves of the present situation of affairs in America, a single blow would finish everything; explains how the enemies' fleet could be surprised and crushed.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Extract from the despatch of M. Berkenro[o]de, Dutch Minister at Paris, concerning certain warlike preparations in France; extract from a German letter concerning the arrival of General Rewitzki from the Court of Vienna, à propos of the trouble with Bavaria. Possibility of a war between England and France.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Offering his services.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Have studied medicine under the best masters and have had experience in the army; they wish to enter the American service as surgeons.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Arrival of Captain Jenkins from Nantucket; reports that General Lee was exchanged for General Prescott; the army in high spirits and in want of nothing; the English driven within Kingsbridge by General Gates, who, it is thought, will attack New York before he joins General Washington.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desiring Franklin to appoint a time and place for an interview; willing to come all the way to Paris to lay before Franklin certain propositions of very great consequence to North American commerce; drops certain hints of the intended proposals but dares not speak further in writing; the need of absolute secrecy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking why he failed to appear at dinner at the house of Mesdames, les princesses de Sapieha and de Sangusko; the ladies were inconsolable. Sending two memoirs from Mlle. Basseporte and messages from Messrs. Reignier and Coder.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Montcarel, Jean-Jacques Le Goüeslier de. Versailles

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begging Franklin to forward the enclosed letter from M. de la Radière to his son in America.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending Franklin a letter from George Michel Bishoff in Sonnenburg.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning the ship Chester, captured by an American privateer and taken to Charlestown; entreats Franklin to consider the circumstances and procure for the losers some indemnification.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging Messrs. Franklin and Deane's letter acquainting him with their purpose to send away the public despatches on Monday next; desires to knwo if this is to be done without consultation upon them or upon the person (unknown to him), to whom they are to be confided.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing the bearer, William Cooper, the son of his eldest brother.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends to Dr. Franklin and Mr. Deane a stilton cheese.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: An officer of the English army, forced to leave England for killing another officer, requests service in the American army.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Complains of a want of consideration for him relative to the sending away of the public despatches; has not been consulted about this matter at all; desires to know why he should be placed in the light of an incapable or suspected person; his close attention to all public business; desires to wait on them with several proposals of importance concerning the public despatches.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is the agent for the Commonwealth of Virginia in the island of Martinique; has been denied the privilege of buying and selling in his own name and compelled to connect himself with a French merchant at the expense of half his commissions; applies to Franklin to have these restrictions suspended in the case of American agents; mentions another French law, the Droit d' Aubainc, which is sufficient to destroy the credit of any foreigners.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begging Franklin to forward the enclosed letter to General Roberdeau whom he is persuaded is related to him.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Surprised that Franklin has paid no attention to his or his brother's repeated requests; trusts that only a pressure of affairs causes this neglect and begs that the desired papers may be returned.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Having read Franklin's interrogation and having examined the beautiful Constitutions, has entirely changed his sentiments; desires an interview with Franklin.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Complaining of unfair treatment by Mr. Deane.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Account of a small difference between Captain Vorvisca and himself; confusion this created; timely arrival of Mr. Williams to whom he refers Franklin for an unprejudiced account of the affair; convinced he has been ill-treated.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Came from Vienna expressly to offer his services to America; is travelling strictly incognito.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Understands that the Abbé Condillac has just come to town; asks Franklin for the letter of recommendation to him which he left in Franklin's hands; a plan which is not yet fit for Franklin's observation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has a wish to help America; his brother's position in the English army; his unexceptional family connections; his military services.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Unable to feed and clothe his wife and five children on his small salary; applies to Franklin for money.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Applies to Franklin for a remedy for dropsy, on behalf of a lady at Vienna.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Served on Captain Wickes's ship, the Reprisal, for a space of twenty months; has been in the hospital three months; is now well again but greatly in need of clothes and money; wages and prize money due him from the ship; desires Franklin to send him a certain sum.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning Lord North's plan of reconciliation; admires the spirit of Franklin's sentiments to Lord Howe; urges the arrest of any fatal treaty with the House of Bourbon. Danger of reporting things said in public counsel.

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Works (Sparks, VIII, 237).

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Millin de la Brosse, Claude-Valentin. Paris

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Renews his request for a settlement of his claim for expenses incurred in America and England whilst in the service of the United States as a military officer.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Michel Bonniot and Eymas Labate. Bordeaux

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing a letter just arrived on the ship Bordelais; cause of the delay; offer their services to Franklin.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: La Goaner and Co. La Corunna

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing the desired accounts. Concerning the seizure by the commanding general of the Province, of certain funds proceeding from prizes taken by Captain Conyngham; also a letter of Arthur Lee's as Commissioner, desiring them to retain at his disposal the half of the net profits of prizes, which belong, in his opinion, to Congress.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Mentioning the titles of the bills moved by Lord North; his opinion that Mr. Hartley gave in too much to the King's and Lord North's temporizing policy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wrote to Franklin in an earlier letter of his being taken prisoner, deprived of everything and brought to Portsmouth whence he proceeded to London. Messrs. Vaughan and Towgood promise him help if Franklin will write them a letter on his behalf; desires to join the brave defenders of liberty.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The bearer, the Baron de Holtzendorff, not having obtained the service he expected is returning to France. Acknowledging Franklin's favors of January 23d, 1777, per Mr. Lutterloh to whom he will show all the civilities in his power.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desiring Franklin's presence, the next day, to superintend the examination of the public papers of the late Thomas Morris; desires to get away to Germany as soon as possible.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: La Goaner and Co. La Coruña

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning the seizure of the funds by the Commander-General of the Province; enclosing a copy of all their accounts with Captain Conyngham; news of the cargo of the Black Prince; feasibility of selling prizes in the above port.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The return of their despatches by Mr. Simeon Deane is an event from which great public consequences may flow; hurt at not being consulted in the matter; points out unpleasant results of this step; desires a consultation on the subject.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Making an appointment to meet Dr. Franklin and Mr. Deane the following day.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Difficulties in the way of his taking passage at once; little difference he has had with Captain Nicholson; kindness of Mr. Williams who wrote Dr. Franklin the enclosed letter on his behalf. Desires a small advance of the amount due him to pay his current expenses.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Melfort, Marie de Berenger, duchesse douairière de. Paris

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Stating her claim to certain settlements in New Jersey and New York through her cousin, Lord Drummond, of Perth; desires an audience with Dr. Franklin.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wishing to know Franklin's address in case he should have occasion to write him from Holland, and giving his own address there.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends him a political pamphlet, by the author's desire.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires to go to America and there pursue his commercial career.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The propriety of postponing his proposition. The necessity of sending the treaties in French; offers to copy them himself. Advises the immediate sailing of the convoy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Discusses the present methods of investigation in medicine; encloses a printed statement composed by himself, of physiological problems deduced from the teachings of Hippocrates.
(In Latin.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His plan for writing a history of the United States; Lord Clives offered him the materials, but the work was to be done under his direction and he preferred to remain free; aid given him by M. Le Sage; asks Franklin's advice as to various books and maps to be consulted. Enclosed letters concerning his exile. Sends his "History of Geneva" desires "Le Bonhomme Richard" in return.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Willing to submit his judgement to Franklin's and deliver to him the trunk containing the late Mr. Thomas Morris's papers; desires an important letter for America to reach Mr. Deane before he sails.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Announcing the arrival, at Dunkirk, of Captain Henry Johnson, late commander of the Lexington, and Eliazad [sic] Johnson, captain of the Dalton; both made their escape from Plymouth prison; desires Franklin's orders relative to Captain Henry Johnson. Total loss of the cargo of the brigantine, I'Hirondelle.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reminding Franklin of the letters of recommendation he brought him last October from Messrs. Raspe and Dalrymple; reasons for his long absence. Will return to Paris later, and wishes to consult Franklin before proceeding to America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging letters of February 1st and 12th. Franklin's advice such that little use can be made of it; as a peace-wisher, not being tall enough to be a peace-maker, he cannot propose the points Franklin hinted at. Always grieved at the treatment Franklin met, with in England. Hopes the past may be forgotten and that both sides may embrace cordially.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The "Ameriquiade." On the war between England and the American Colonies. Predicting its disastrous results for England. Dedicated to Benjamin Franklin, Silas Deane and Arthur Lee, American Commissioners in France.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Lord North's conciliatory bill; Lord George Germain's hearty concurrence with it and strong desire for peace.

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Works (Sparks, VIII, 245).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends by Captain All, the Parliamentary Register, the Remonstrance, newspapers, etc; the captain a sincere well-wisher to America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Captain Lemaire has agreed to procure, for Virginia, such articles as are absolutely necessary for her defense; he carries an invoice to William Lee; question of paying for the articles with tobacco; begs Franklin to render aid in this matter. Chesapeake Bay guarded by English ships; no hope of facing Britain on the water unless assisted by France.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Postponing the meeting till the following day at Passy; begs for the Committee's letters.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Question of the 50,000 livres being paid.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Rejoiced at M. Chaumont's success. If the 50,000 livres are paid in America, asks how he is to be reimbursed for his expenses and commissisons. Reasons why he does not wish to take his powers form Mr. Lee; Mr. Morris's failure to keep his part of the agreement made between them; refers Franklin to the enclosed extracts [4 p.] for his entire connection with the Lion. His brother Jack to sail in a day or two.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Duchesse de Grammont still at St. Nazare; question of a new convoy. Arrival of Captain Chapman, from Boston, in the brig Nantes; no further news from America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Affair of the prizes. Concerning the acceptance of the bill for 50,000 livres; disposition of the effects of Mr. Josiah Crosby, who died of smallpox.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Unhappy at having his letters neglected; his reasons for desiring to be informed of anything of importance; protection the Americans meet with in the ports of Martinique; their prizes sold openly. No attention paid to the violent clamor of the English governors; daring behavior of an English frigate in capturing an American privateer under the very guns of a French fort.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Honored with several letters by the hands of foreign gentlemen, desirous of serving the cause; impossible, owing to their ignorance of the language, to find places for them. Very anxious to obtain some news of his father whom he fears is prevented from communicating with him.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Intends setting out as soon as his gout and the weather permit, for the Court of Tuscany to which Congress has appointed him; desires to be informed of any proceedings entered into with the Court of France, also wishes copies of any treaties concluded with that Court.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing his son John who is about to become an inmate in the house of Messrs. Barton and Co., at Bordeaux; requesting Franklin to give him any necessary advice.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Great variety of opinions concerning America. Description of a debate in Parliament concerning a peace in America; opinions of the Dukes of Grafton and Richmond and Lords Weymoth, Radnor, Hillsborough, Suffolk and Temple.

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Works (Sparks, VIII, 246).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending the keys of the trunk containing Mr. Thomas Morris's papers; desires an answer that night to his letters to the Commissioners relative to the commercial agents.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing extracts from ministerial despatches; trouble caused by the arrival at Lisbon of the English vessel the Hero, suspected of being a privateer. Possible rupture between France and England. Conversation held with the Grand Pensionnaire of Amsterdam showing the attitude of Holland towards America. Lawsuit in Amsterdam owing to the purchase of sugar from American vessels by the French who loaded it on Dutch vessels.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Jacques Rocquette, T.A. Elsevier, and Fréres Rocquette. Rotterdam

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Two vessels are ready to depart, one to Curaçan and the other to St. Eustatia; will take charge of any letters they may have to those places. Prices of tobacco and rice; glad to receive consignments of these articles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The abuse of power by Mr. William Lee as Commercial Agent, in seizing, privately searching and carrying off the books, papers, etc., of Messrs. Willing Morris and Co. and the private correspondence of Robert Morris with his deceased brother; considers it an arbitrary insult to the laws of their country; in need of Franklin's advice and opinion as to his future conduct in this matter.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Duchesse de Grammont still waiting their permission to proceed to sea. Attempt made to procure a ship to carry the remaining goods.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires to ship a cargo of tobacco but the custom's officer in Bordeaux refuses to give him the necessary clearance papers; begs Franklin to speak to M. Necker in order that the edict of the King of 1721 may be enforced.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks for a commission in the army.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A jesting pretense of being his spiritual adviser; absolves him of all sins past and present provided he loves God, America and herself; acquits him of all the seven cardinal sins, except a weakness for women.
(In French.)

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Putnam's Monthly, Dec., 1906, 310.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is absolutely convinced of the effect of the bullets; desires only two hundred guineas for his secret.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends with this letter a package of his printed papers; trusts the papers may be useful to Franklin's young compatriots.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Writes on behalf of his brother, who desires to pursue his commercial career in America
[see VIII, 139].
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Complains of the delay in placing before the Commissioners his proposition about appointing agents in the ports. An account of his journey to Nantes to take possession of Mr. Thomas Morris's papers and the unjustifiable behaviour of Mr. Ross in that matter; resents the letter [see VIII, 157] Mr. Ross wrote to the Commissioners concerning him, and their attitude in approving it.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The case of Captain James Babson; his prizes were restored by the French; injustice of this; will compensation be made Captain Babson for his loss?

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends a copy of two commissions delivered to him by the respective Governors of Virginia and North Carolina, as their agent for receiving and selling. Begs to be allowed to forward his letters under Franklin's care to friends in America. Desires new of two brigantines, in which he has an interest.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His proposed visit to America. Takes advantage of the Comte de Conway's recommendation to offer his services to Franklin.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending two of Franklin's banker's books, which he found among his papers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Extracts from ministerial despatches concerning European affairs; trouble between Austria and Bavaria; war-like preparations; rumored war between Turkey and Russia. Desires to know what he must say if questioned concerning Mr. J. P. Merkle and his enterprise. Acknowledging Mr. Wm. Lee's favor of the 8th inst.; will publish his good news in the Gazette.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has received no intimation that his six previous letters to Franklin arrived safely. Warns him against the five bribed and bribing emissaries sent by England to make a show of transacting peace; results to be expected should America reject proposals of reconciliation. Sketches the indemnification England ought to grant. Laughs at the dreaded alliance between France and America; no ally in need of protection was ever benefitted by France.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Account of his journey to Coruna and the difficulties of weather, roads, etc. Curiosity of the people as to his business. Will embark that evening in disguise. News of Captain Conyngham.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Hopes to shake off the gout soon and pay Franklin a visit; refers him to the bearer, Mr. Nathaniel Dowse, for all particulars.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Recommending M. de Fontevieux; his wish to embark on the Duchesse de Grammont. News of Mr. Deane's recall; slanders which may arise from this circumstance.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Informed by Mr. Grand that his bills still remain unapproved; fears such delay may hurt the credit of his paper.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begs for information concerning the principal houses dealing in tobacco, rice, sugar, etc., the sort of merchandise it is expedient to send to America, the safest route for his ships to take, and the difference of money, etc.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has sent the wine Franklin ordered; the bottle of white wine is a small mark of his attchment; encloses the accounts for the other bottles.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing M. Monié, a painter of portraits, to Franklin's notice.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His desire, and that of other merchants, to see Franklin in Holland; would take that opportunity to introduce him to the principal leaders at Court; thinks it would tend to the mutual service and public good.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Card of introduction.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Declines to engage in a discussion with Franklin on the Ten Commandments. Points out the reserve and discretion in conduct which women are obliged to observe and the liberty allowed to men in their relations with the opposite sex.
Postscript about a collection of Scotch airs received from Mr. Alexander.
(In French.)
